author: The Telegraph
title: Love popping Bubble Wrap? Read this
text: A great outpouring of grief has followed the news that popping B ubble Wrap will soon be a thing of the past . The makers have come up with a new design. This column is here to bring comfort to people preparing themselves for painful withdrawal symptoms . The truth is, there are still many other utterly pointless time-wasting activities to enjoy, without even having to resort to selfies or Twitter. The Japanese version of Bubble Wrap (Getty) A blister pack of pills is a handy tool for the enthusiastic popper, with the added benefit of projecting a tiny missile across the room. With practice you can get a paracetamol caplet to fly a good long way. Why not keep a record of the greatest distances you achieve ? It is always good to return to the traditional futile occupations which have been handed down from generation to generation. We can twang elastic bands just as our forefathers have done or perhaps play a series of solo games of noughts and crosses. You can still twang an elastic band (Paul Grover) Making chains of paperclips or punching holes in blank sheets of paper have kept young executives sane for many years. And remember, a stapler is the idler’s best friend. If it’s the actual popping you will miss , you may like to the satisfying sound of the index finger tweaking the inside of your cheek. And jabbing the seal of a jar of instant coffee never fails to delight. Other sounds are available, like the rude raspberry when you blow on a blade of grass wedged between the bases of your thumbs. Remember your school days when you could summon up a burp at will? Men might like to try this one: tug out a single nostril hair and amaze yourself with the magnificent sneeze that follows. Pop pop pop! (Alamy) Or for all the family, rub sun cream on the soles of your feet then listen to the impressive squelch as you walk about in flip-flops. Next week: Fun with Clingfilm.
